Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Just because someone edits a major publication does not mean that they can teach writing. Roger's course was unplanned, badly managed, expectations were unclear, and had an unclear goal/metric of success. He had clearly had conversations with Streebeigh and Klinkenborg, tried to adopt the best practices at both, and was unable to do so. I've taken both of the other courses, which were significantly better run and taught. The course struggled for three main reasons. First, the purpose of a course application is to select a cohort of students adequately prepared and interested in the course material. This course had a mixture of ESL and native english speakers with a variety of writing levels and backgrounds. The course struggled to find both a common starting point and a shared meaning of success because of this. The course could have been structured around one-on-one writing/editing partnerships, which would have offered opportunities for growth to both sets of writers. The second reason the course struggled was that Roger needs a hearing aid. I understand that this may be a complicated issue, but the course cannot be taught again unless Roger is physically capable of hearing class discussions. The third reason this class struggled was because Roger seemed to have given little thought to teaching writing. I would expect that he'd do better at teaching a course that was entirely designed to produce articles acceptable for publication by E360 -- indeed, I think this would be a great course to teach!
Roger is an excellent instructor and I have affirmed my confidence as a writer in his class. I am forever in debt to his tutelage.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The textbook used in this course has been very helpful for me.

The selected readings were interesting and diverse. Unfortunately, the discussion of them in class (which took significant time) added nothing to the quality of the readings, because we didn't have a common understanding of what was actually worth talking about with regards to readings -- and we didn't have guidance to build this over time, which means that our discussions of the readings continued to be useless. I remember a particular time when someone said that she had nothing to say about the reading - and that the author did a poor job -- because she wasn't interested in whales, so why would she have read it in detail to learn anything about the writing?
His feedback on your papers in the office hours after class
Writing and the readings

This is really a place for students to learn creative non-fiction writing. And most FES students should learn to write better. It is easy to claim to be a writer, but it is harder to really write something that people read and accept. There's too much grandstanding in the field of environment right now and it mounts to nothing but singing in silos. Frankly, this class ought to be a full semester long. It is better than most classes I've taken at FES...

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I've noted aspects that need improvement in questions 13 and 14.
Didn't feel the comments necessarily helped my writing and I didn't think many of the readings were that engaging
Perhaps students can read different part of a workshop piece instead of letting Roger do the job all the time.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: very effective

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Writing has always been my weakness. This course improved my writing greatly.
I'm interested in journalism so writing better is important

Absolutely necessary for ANY FES students. How can one be a leader if one can't communicate? And by communications, I refer to connecting with a wider audience, bridging the political gap, and raising a stronger awareness for nature. Frankly, most professors have failed that.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I had to improve my writing skill.
I was hoping to learn about writing for a science publication like E360. The course did not satisfy this goal.
To improve my science communication skills
I wanted to be a better writer. And I believe I did.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. It did.
No. The other writing courses at FES, offered by Fred Streebeigh and Verlyn Klinkenbourg, were much better courses.
yes
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you want to improve your writing in a short time, this course is for you.
Take other writing courses.
I nice short course where you get to write every week
Really put effort into writing each workshop piece. Take each word and each piece you write to be the last. And you will grow like never before.
